page.title: Language policies of Canada's provinces and territories

revision.text:
The '''language policies of Canada's province and territories''' vary substantially between different regions and also between different eras.
From the 1890s until the 1960s, English was the only language in which most government services were provided outside of [[History of Quebec|Quebec]] (which was functionally bilingual) and using French in the courts or in schools was often illegal. These developments led to fears by [[French Canadian|French-Canadian]] nationalists that French speakers would be assimilated into the increasingly Anglophone culture of Ontario, leading the [[Royal Commission on Bilingualism and Biculturalism]] (1963â1969) to recommend that the [[Government of Canada]] and [[Provinces and territories of Canada|all provinces]] offer more services in French.
Since that time, Quebec has used provincial law to encourage the use of French (see [[Charter of the French Language]]) at the expense of other languages, while the other provinces have begun to offer more and more services in French and in [[Languages of Canada|other languages besides English]], including [[Languages of Canada#Aboriginal languages|Aboriginal languages]] and [[immigrant language]]s.<ref name="Morton2002">{{cite book|author=Frederick Lee Morton|title=Law, Politics and the Judicial Process in Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dj_4_H35nmYC&pg=PA509|year=2002|publisher=University of Calgary Press|isbn=978-1-55238-046-8|page=509}}</ref> The [[Amendments to the Constitution of Canada|1982 amendments]] to the [[Constitution of Canada]] included a right of minority-language education that has forced policy changes in all of the provinces. Quebec is unique in requiring private businesses to use French and requiring immigrants to send their children to French-language schools. In other provinces there is no requirement that businesses use a particular language, but English predominates, and immigrants may send their children to English, French or third-language schools.<ref name="Carens1995">{{cite book|author=Joseph H. Carens|title=Is Quebec Nationalism Just?: Perspectives from Anglophone Canada|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-agrT6RVkwoC&pg=PA61|year=1995|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press|isbn=978-0-7735-1342-6|page=61}}</ref>
== History (before 1982) == {{further|Timeline of official languages policy in Canada}}
At the time of [[Canadian Confederation|Confederation]] in 1867, English and French were made the [[official language]]s of debate in the [[Parliament of Canada]] and the [[Quebec Legislature|Parliament of Quebec]]. No specific policies were enacted for the other provinces, and no provisions were made for the official languages to be used in other elements of the government such the courts, schools, post offices, and so on. The official language policies of the provinces and territories were initially set when they were created by the federal government, or in the case of provinces that were separate colonies before joining Confederation ([[Dominion of Newfoundland|Newfoundland]], [[History of Prince Edward Island|Prince Edward Island]], and [[History of British Columbia|British Columbia]]) were inherited from their own histories. Language policies in all provinces have evolved over time in response to changing demographics, public attitudes, and legal rulings.
=== The Prairies === Prior to becoming part of Canada in 1869, English was a minority language in the [[Canadian Prairies|Prairies]], where French and Aboriginal languages were more common. The arrival of settlers from [[History of Ontario|Ontario]], the [[British Isles]], and the [[United States]] changed the demographic balance, however. One of the outcomes of the [[Red River Rebellion]] of 1870 was the creation of [[History of Manitoba|Manitoba]] as an officially bilingual province, to protect the French-speaking [[MÃ©tis people (Canada)|MÃ©tis]] from being overpowered by the incoming English speaking settlers. This guarantee failed, however, and in the aftermath of the [[Manitoba Schools Question]], that province was allowed to become officially English-only, until these policies were declared unconstitutional in 1985.
The [[Northwest Territories Act]] of 1891 made English and French official languages in the rest of the [[Western Canada|Canadian West]]. But in 1892 the [[Legislative Assembly of the Northwest Territories|Legislature of the Northwest Territories]] declared itself English-only.
This trend continued to the creation of the new provinces of [[History of Alberta|Alberta]] and [[History of Saskatchewan|Saskatchewan]] in 1905, and beyond. {{quote|By the time Alberta was made a province in 1905, the French language had been dealt a series of aggressive blows, and the use of French in government, the courts and schools was made illegal.|Alberta Online Encyclopedia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abheritage.ca/stvincent-stpaul/franco_alta/themes_language_en.html |title=Alberta Online Encyclopedia - Saint Vincent and St. Paul - Language |publisher=Abheritage.ca |date=2010-12-08 |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref>}}
== Effect of the ''Charter'' on the provinces and territories == [[Section Twenty-three of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]] guarantees that Canadian-born or educated parents (not recent immigrants) have a right to educate their children in their choice of either French or English wherever there are "sufficient numbers". This was a major change in that education is normally considered solely provincial jurisdiction, and policy had been [[Majority rule|majoritarian]]. Court cases such as ''[[Doucet-Boudreau v Nova Scotia (Minister of Education)]]'' have indicated that this is a [[Negative and positive rights|positive right]] that demands timely and sufficient action from the provincial governments.
==Officially bilingual or multilingual provinces/territories== New Brunswick and Canada's three territories have all given official status to more than one language. In the case of New Brunswick, this means perfect equality. In the other cases, the recognition sometimes amounts to a formal recognition of official languages, but limited services in official languages other than English. Manitoba was officially bilingual at its creation, became officially Anglophone only, but this was later reversed by the courts.
=== The territories === {{see also|Franco-TÃ©nois|Franco-Yukonnais}} *[[Northwest Territories]]: [[Chipewyan language|Chipewyan]], [[Cree language|Cree]], English, French, [[Gwichâin language|Gwichâin]], [[Inuinnaqtun]], [[Inuktitut]], [[Inuvialuktun]], [[Slavey language|North Slavey]], South Slavey and [[TÅÄ±Ì¨chÇ« language|TÅÄ¯chÇ« or Dogrib]]. *[[Nunavut]]: English, Inuktitut, Inuinnaqtun, and French. *[[Yukon]]: English and French.
=== New Brunswick === New Brunswick has been officially bilingual since the passing of the ''[[Official Languages in New Brunswick Act (1969)]]''. This was complemented by ''[[An Act Recognizing the Equality of the Two Official Linguistic Communities in New Brunswick]]'' in 1981. New Brunswick's bilingualism was constitutionally enshrined in the ''Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms'' in 1982. The ''Charter'' was amended in 1993 to clarify that the two language communities are legally equal. In 1999 the [[Supreme Court of Canada]] ruled in ''[[Moncton (City) v. Charlebois]]'' that New Brunswick's official bilingualism also applied to municipalities in the province. In 2002 the ''[[Official Languages Act (New Brunswick)|Official Languages Act]]'' became New Brunswick's new language law, leading to the creation of the [[Office of the Commissioner of Official Languages for New Brunswick]] in 2003.<ref>[http://www.legal-info-legale.nb.ca/en/.../History_of_Language_Rights_ENG.pdf ]{{dead link|date=November 2011}}</ref>
=== Manitoba === {{see also|Franco-Manitoban}} {{quote|Manitoba stands out amongst the provinces as a province with a small Francophone linguistic minority but above-average constitutional protection of this minority.|Fraser Institute<ref>Vallincourt et al., viii</ref>}} Manitoba was established as an officially bilingual province under section 23 of the [[Manitoba Act]], 1870. However, in subsequent years the provincial government moved to end French-language services and become English-only. In the famous Supreme Court of Canada case ''[[Reference Re Manitoba Language Rights]]'' of 1985 the court found these policies unconstitutional. The province of Manitoba is now overwhelmingly English-speaking and the first language of the courts, government ministries, and schools is English. However, in order to comply with the court's ruling the province is required to provide nearly all its services in French (as well as English). The government's policy is summarized in the ''French Language Services Policy'', last updated in March 1999.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.mb.ca/fls-slf/pdf/fls_policy.pdf|format=PDF|title=French-Language Services Policy |date=May 2017|website=Gov.mb.ca|accessdate=25 January 2018}}</ref>
== Regionalized bilingualism: Ontario == {{see also|Franco-Ontarian}} Ontario has a regionalized language policy, where part of the province is English-only and other areas are bilingual. Province-wide services (such as websites and toll-free telephone numbers) are provided in both English and French. However individuals only have a ''right'' to French-language services in certain designated regions of the province under the ''[[French Language Services Act]]'' (1986). There are 25 regions so designated. These are: areas with 10% or more Francophones; urban centres with 5,000 or more Francophones; and areas previously designated by the [[Government of Ontario]] between 1978 and 1985.<ref name="ontario.ca">{{cite web|url=https://www.ontario.ca/en/communities/francophones/profile/ONT05_024287.html |title=Profile of Ontario's Francophone Community, 2009: Concepts and Definitions |publisher=Ontario.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref> Notably this includes [[Toronto]], the provincial capital and Canada's largest municipality (although not all of the [[regional municipalities]] of the [[Greater Toronto Area|GTA]] are included), and the [[National Capital Region (Canada)|National Capital Region]] including [[Ottawa]], the national capital, as well as many other cities, counties, districts, townships, and towns.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ofa.gov.on.ca/en/flsa-mapdesig.html |title=Government of Ontario - Office of Francophone Affairs: Map of Designated Areas |publisher=Ofa.gov.on.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref> For the purposes of the policy, the definition of a "Francophone" was broadened in 2009. Previously it included only mother-tongue speakers, however it now includes [[Allophone (Canada)|allophones]] (people whose [[first language]] is neither French or English) who "have particular knowledge of French as an official language and use French at home, including many recent immigrants to Ontario for whom French is the language of integration".<ref name="ontario.ca"/>
==Officially French-only: Quebec== Until 1969, Quebec was the only officially bilingual province in Canada and most public institutions functioned in both languages. English was also used in the legislature, government commissions and courts.
''[[An Act to promote the French language in QuÃ©bec]]'' was passed in 1969 by the [[Union Nationale (Quebec)|Union Nationale]] government of [[Jean-Jacques Bertrand]]. It required the [[Ministry of Education, Recreation and Sports (Quebec)|education ministry]] to ensure that French as a [[second language]] was taught to all English-speakers and immigrants in Quebec, but allowed [[QuÃ©bÃ©cois (word)|Quebecers]] freedom of choice in deciding in which language to educate their children. This was considered too weak by many [[Quebec nationalism|Quebec nationalists]], leading to the creation of the [[Mouvement QuÃ©bec franÃ§ais]] and increased support for the new [[Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois]].
From 1968 to 1973, the [[Commission of Inquiry on the Situation of the French Language and Linguistic Rights in Quebec]] investigated how to strengthen the position of French in Quebec. Its recommendations led to the passage of the [[Official Language Act (Quebec)|''Official Language Act'']] or "Bill 22" in 1974 by the [[Quebec Liberal Party]] government of [[Robert Bourassa]]. This made French the sole official language of Quebec and required its use in business.
Bill 22 was replaced by the ''Charter of the French Language'' (Bill 101) by Quebec's [[National Assembly of Quebec|National Assembly]] in August 1977, under the Parti QuÃ©bÃ©cois government led by [[RenÃ© LÃ©vesque]]. It is structured as a list of rights, where everyone in Quebec has the right to be served in French by the government and businesses, and also provides rights for speakers of English and aboriginal languages. Most government services are available in both French and English. Regional institutions in the [[Nunavik]] region of [[Nord-du-QuÃ©bec|northern Quebec]] offer services in [[Inuktitut]] and [[Cree language|Cree]].
Several legal challenges have been raised against Bill 101 in the ongoing [[legal dispute over Quebec's language policy]]. In 1988, the Supreme Court of Canada ruled in ''[[Ford v Quebec (AG)]]'' that the ban on outdoor signs in languages other than French was unconstitutional. The government of Quebec choose to invoke the "[[Section Thirty-three of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms|notwithstanding clause]]" to shield the legislation from the courts. The [[United Nations Commission on Human Rights]] ruled similarly in ''[[Ballantyne v Canada]]'' in 1993. The ban on non-French signs was lifted with the passage of [[Bill 86]] in 1993.
==Officially English with services in French and other languages== Most provinces have laws that make either English or both English and French the official language(s) of the legislature and the courts, but may also have separate policies in regards to education and the bureaucracy.
=== Alberta === {{see also|Franco-Albertan}} Alberta inherited its English-only status from the Northwest Territories in 1905, and this was strengthened over time. The [[Language Act]] 1988, reaffirmed the unilingual English nature of the province,<ref>Vaillancourt, et al., viii</ref> while recognizing a right to use French in the [[Legislative Assembly of Alberta]] and before certain courts.<ref name="municipalaffairs.gov.ab.ca">{{cite web|url=http://www.municipalaffairs.gov.ab.ca/documents/Francophone_Secretariat_Library/Alberta_-_Profil_linguistique_-_eng.pdf|title=Municipal Affairs: Error Message - 404 Page Not Found|first=Alberta|last=Government|website=www.municipalaffairs.gov.ab.ca}}</ref> The Language Policy in Education (1978) requires [[Board of education|school boards]] to establish French programs at the request of a local advisory committee.<ref name="municipalaffairs.gov.ab.ca"/> The [[Schools Act]] recognizes a right to instruction in French for the official language minority (1988) and right of Francophones to manage their own schools (1993).<ref name="municipalaffairs.gov.ab.ca"/> Laws are drafted solely in English and there is no legal requirement that they be translated into French. French may be used [[Speech|orally]] in all [[Provincial Court of Alberta|provincial courts]] in Alberta. There is no requirement that healthcare services be provided in French, and it is left up to the initiative of individual hospitals and clinics.<ref name="municipalaffairs.gov.ab.ca"/> There is no requirement that [[social services]] be provided in French and this is left up to individual [[Non-governmental organization|NGOs]] and charities that work with the provincial government.<ref name="municipalaffairs.gov.ab.ca"/> Other government services are provided in English only, except where the [[Executive Council of Alberta|provincial government]] sees a need for French, including tourism and immigration, or where the federal government has provided funding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pch.gc.ca/offlangoff/entente-agreement/services/ab/index-eng.cfm |title=Canadian Heritage - Services - Alberta |publisher=Pch.gc.ca |date=2008-12-09 |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref> There is no official policy requiring municipalities in Alberta to provide services in French, but the Alberta Bilingual Municipalities Network includes the communities of [[Beaumont, Alberta|Beaumont]], [[Legal, Alberta|Legal]], [[Falher]], [[Plamondon, Alberta|Plamondon]], [[Morinville]], [[St. Albert, Alberta|St. Albert]], [[St. Paul, Alberta|St. Paul]], [[Bonnyville]] and the [[Municipal District of Smoky River No. 130|Smoky River Municipal District]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.alberta.ca/release.cfm?xID=471088AC318FE-0275-478A-29387B822D1D55A4|title=Alberta unveils first French policy {{!}} Alberta.ca|last=Alberta|first=Government of|website=www.alberta.ca|access-date=2017-06-27}}</ref> Since 1993 there have been distinct [[List of school authorities in Alberta|separate and public]] Francophone school boards in Alberta in addition to the existing [[Education in Alberta|public]] and [[separate school]] boards which also offer [[French immersion]].<ref name="municipalaffairs.gov.ab.ca"/> Besides French the government does not offer most services in many other languages, but there are exceptions. Official government toll-free lines related subjects like family violence and gambling are available in 170 languages.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://alberta.ca/home/NewsFrame.cfm?ReleaseID=/acn/200810/24672536C5473-D26A-1309-E36353818E9D0FF7.html |title=Government of Alberta |publisher=Alberta.ca |date=2008-10-31 |accessdate=2011-11-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006185445/http://alberta.ca/home/NewsFrame.cfm?ReleaseID=%2Facn%2F200810%2F24672536C5473-D26A-1309-E36353818E9D0FF7.html# |archive-date=2011-10-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The government publishes an educational curriculum to assists teachers of Chinese, German, Italian, Japanese, Latin, Punjabi, Spanish, and Ukrainian,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://education.alberta.ca/teachers/program/interlang.aspx |title=Alberta Education - International Languages Programs |publisher=Education.alberta.ca |date=2006-12-28 |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref> as well as of Cree and [[Blackfoot language|Blackfoot]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://education.alberta.ca/teachers/program/fnmi/programs.aspx |title=Alberta Education - Programs of Study |publisher=Education.alberta.ca |date=2006-12-28 |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref>
In June 2017 the province unveiled a [http://www.culturetourism.alberta.ca/francophone-secretariat/english/docs/FINAL_French%20Policy%20Document_English%20for%20Web_13JUNE17.pdf new French Policy] aimed at improving services for Franco-Albertans.<ref name=":0" /> The province maintains a partial French version of its website, bonjour.alberta.ca.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bonjour.alberta.ca/|title=Bonjour Alberta|last=Government of Alberta|first=|date=|website=www.bonjour.alberta.ca|language=en|access-date=2017-06-27}}</ref>
=== Nova Scotia === Nova Scotia has no legal requirement to provide any services in a language other than English, which was already well-established as the official language when the province joined Confederation in 1867. However the province has an Office of Gaelic Affairs whose mission is "to work with Nova Scotians in the renewal of [[Canadian Gaelic|Gaelic language]] and culture in the Province"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gov.ns.ca/oga/about_us.asp?lang=en |title=About Us - Office of Gaelic Affairs - Government of Nova Scotia |publisher=Gov.ns.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref> and an Office of Acadian Affairs: {{quote|to offer advice and support to provincial government departments, offices, agencies and Crown corporations so that they can develop and adapt policies, programs, and services that reflect the needs of the [[Acadians|Acadian]] and francophone community.|Office of Acadian Affairs<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.ns.ca/acadian/en/index.htm |title=Acadian Affairs - Home |publisher=Gov.ns.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref>}} The province also maintains a French-language web portal, gov.ns.ca/bonjour<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gov.ns.ca/bonjour/ |title=Bonjour! | Government of Nova Scotia |publisher=Gov.ns.ca |date=2011-07-25 |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref>
=== Prince Edward Island === {{quote|During the first half of the 20th century, there were 60 French language schools in Prince Edward Island. However, due to a consolidation of the school system, the number of French schools declined to only one by the late 70s. A second school opened in 1980 and, 20 years later, three new French schools opened in the province.|http://www.gov.pe.ca/focus/segment.php3?number=813}} The French Language School Board was created on July 1, 1990.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edu.pe.ca/cslf/english/english.html |title=English |publisher=Edu.pe.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref> This was followed by the opening of new French-language school in [[Summerside, Prince Edward Island|Summerside]]-[[Miscouche]], [[Prince County, Prince Edward Island|West Prince]], and [[North Rustico|Rustico]] in 2000, and [[Souris, Prince Edward Island|Souris]] in 2003. The Francophone Affairs Division was established on April 1, 1989<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.pe.ca/eco/aafa-info/index.php3 |title=Executive Council Office: Executive Council Office Department Guide |publisher=Gov.pe.ca |date=1989-04-01 |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref> Under the French Language Services Act (2000), Prince Edward Island made a variety of mostly non-binding commitments to provide services in French, but according to a government report (as of 2005), many sections of the Act have not proclaimed into law, as the province is still in the process of building its capacity to deliver services in French.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.pe.ca/photos/original/afa_frenchprogr.pdf |title=French Language Services Report |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref>
=== Saskatchewan === {{see also|Fransaskois}} In Saskatchewan, a 1968 amendment to the School Act permitted the establishment of designated French schools. Prior to this date, English was the only language which could be used as a language of instruction in Saskatchewan schools.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sasked.gov.sk.ca/docs/policy/multi/hert.html.waq13102009 |title=Multicultural Education and Heritage Language Education policies |publisher=Sasked.gov.sk.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-11-02 }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The [[Language Act]] {{quote|provides that all acts and regulations can be enacted, printed and published in English or in English and French. The Act also provides that both English and French may be used in the Legislative Assembly and in Saskatchewan courts. However, the rules of court must be in both languages.|- Ministry of Justice and Attorney General of Saskatchewan.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.justice.gov.sk.ca/Default.aspx?DN=3c7a2fa5-8420-48d3-836d-87dd8972149e |title=The Language Act - Justice and Attorney General - Government of Saskatchewan |publisher=Justice.gov.sk.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-11-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720033341/http://www.justice.gov.sk.ca/Default.aspx?DN=3c7a2fa5-8420-48d3-836d-87dd8972149e |archivedate=2011-07-20 |df= }}</ref>}} In 2010, the Government of Saskatchewan launched a bilingual website that indexes all the services it provides in French: bonjour.gov.sk.ca<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bonjour.gov.sk.ca/Default.aspx?DN=ebd9edd0-fecd-4503-b6f7-70a7366de4c4&l=English |title=About - Bonjour - Government of Saskatchewan |publisher=Bonjour.gov.sk.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref>
==''De facto'' English only==
=== British Columbia === {{see also|Franco-Columbian}} Access to French-language education in British Columbia is determined not only by ''Charter'' rights under Section 23, but also by a provincial policy decision to extend French-language schooling to francophone non-citizens living in British Columbia. There are 59 regional English language school boards in the province and [[Conseil scolaire francophone de la Colombie-Britannique|one province-wide francophone board]]. There is one French language college ([[Educacentre College]]), no French-language universities but some French-medium instruction at [[Simon Fraser University]].
Outside of education, there is no legal framework for minority language services by the civil service or the courts.<ref>Vallincourt et al., 9</ref>
=== Newfoundland and Labrador === {{see also|Franco-Newfoundlander}} Many Aboriginal and European languages were once widely spoken in Newfoundland and Labrador. However, Britain eventually gained firm and unchallenged control of the island and adjacent coast following the French defeat in the [[Seven Years' War]], and English then became the language of administration and commerce, as in most of the [[British Empire]]. In isolated fishing villages many minority languages persisted in private use, however, until the coming of standardized education in the 19th, and more so the 20th centuries. When Newfoundland joined Confederation in 1949 it had already used English as the sole language of government for several centuries. Today, Newfoundland is the most linguistically homogeneous province in Canada. In 1999, 98% of the population spoke only English as their sole mother tongue.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heritage.nf.ca/society/language.html |title=Language: Newfoundland and Labrador Heritage |publisher=Heritage.nf.ca |date= |accessdate=2011-11-02}}</ref> The [[Government of Newfoundland and Labrador]] has no statutory language policy, simply having inherited English from colonial times. The [[Newfoundland (island)|island of Newfoundland]] was once the homeland of the [[Beothuk]] language, and also seen some [[Mi'kmaq language|Mi'kmaq]] speakers. The [[Labrador]] coast is home to the [[Innu-aimun]] and [[Inuttut]] languages. Newfoundland was also home to unique regional dialects of the [[Newfoundland French|French]] and [[Irish language in Newfoundland|Irish Gaelic]] languages, now extinct, as well as smaller groups of [[Old Norse]], [[Basque language|Basque]], Spanish, Portuguese, German, and [[Scottish Gaelic|Scots Gaelic]] speakers. Today the Government offers minimal French-language services through its French-language webisite,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.exec.gov.nl.ca/frenchservices|title=Office of French Services - Bureau des services en franÃ§ais - Human Resource Secretariat|first=Service|last=NL|website=www.exec.gov.nl.ca}}</ref> in all other respects, it is English-only, including in the legislature, the courts, the schools, and the civil service.

==Evaluation of provincial language policy== In its January 2012 report on the costs and benefits of official bilingualism at the provincial level in Canada, the [[Right-wing politics|right-wing]] [[think tank]], the [[Fraser Institute]], identified several potential methods for classifying the provinces based on language circumstances and policies (territories were not included).
First it stated that linguistic minorities were only of a significant size in three provinces, either in absolute numbers (Quebec [575,000] and Ontario [489,000]) or as a proportion (New Brunswick [just over 30%]), while in the other seven provinces minority communities are quite small, as low as 1.3% in British Columbia<ref>Vaillancourt, et al., v</ref>
Second, the report suggested that in six of the provinces, governments only offer those minority-language services they are obliged to under Section 23 of the ''Charter'' (i.e. education). In three provinces (Manitoba, New Brunswick, and Quebec) there are other constitutional rights that come into play, over and above Section 23. In Ontario, there is a developed policy of statutory (not constitutional) minority language rights.<ref>Vaillancourt, et al., vi</ref>

{{Blacklisted-links|1= *http://www.hunmagyar.org/turan/caucasus/index.html *:''Triggered by \bhunmagyar\.org\b on the local blacklist''|bot=Cyberbot II|invisible=false}} {{more footnotes|date=June 2011}} [[File:Caucasus-ethnic en.svg|thumb|upright=1.59|Ethnolinguistic groups in the Caucasus region]] The [[Caucasus|Caucasian]] languages are a large and extremely varied array of languages spoken by more than ten million people in and around the [[Caucasus Mountains]], which lie between the [[Black Sea]] and the [[Caspian Sea]]. [[Comparative method (linguistics)|Linguistic comparison]] allows these languages to be classified into several [[language families]], with little or no discernible affinity to each other. However, the languages of the Caucasus are sometimes mistakenly referred to as a ''family'' of languages. == Families indigenous to the Caucasus == Three of these families have no current members outside the Caucasus, and are considered indigenous to the area. The term '''Caucasian languages''' is generally restricted to these families, which are spoken by about 11.2 million people. * '''[[Kartvelian languages|Kartvelian]]''' language family with a total of about 5.2 million speakers. Includes [[Georgian language|Georgian]], the official language of [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], with four million speakers, [[Svan language|Svan]], [[Mingrelian language|Mingrelian]] and [[Laz language|Laz]]. * '''[[Northeast Caucasian languages|Northeast Caucasian]]''', also called the '''Nakho-Dagestanian''' or '''Caspian''' family, with a total of about 3.8 million speakers. Includes the [[Chechen language]] with 1.5 million speakers, the [[Avar language]] with 1 million speakers, the [[Ingush language]] with 500,000 speakers, the [[Lezgian language]] with 800,000 speakers, and others. * '''[[Northwest Caucasian languages|Northwest Caucasian]]''', also called the '''Abkhazo-Adyghean''' or '''Pontic''' family, with a total of about 2.5 million speakers. Includes the [[Kabardian language]], with one million speakers. It is commonly believed that all Caucasian languages have a large number of [[consonant]]s. While this is certainly true for most members of the Northeast and Northwest Caucasian families (inventories range up to the 80â84 consonants of [[Ubykh language|Ubykh]]), the consonant inventories of the South Caucasian languages are not nearly as extensive, ranging from 28 (Georgian) to 30 ([[Laz language|Laz]]) â comparable to languages like [[Russian phonology|Russian]] (up to 37 consonant [[Phoneme|phonemes]], depending on definition), [[Arabic phonology|Arabic]] (28 phonemes), and Western European languages (often more than 20 phonemes). The autochthonous languages of the Caucasus share some [[areal feature]]s, such as the presence of [[ejective consonant]]s and a highly [[agglutinative]] structure, and, with the sole exception of [[Mingrelian language|Mingrelian]], all of them exhibit a greater or lesser degree of [[ergativity]]. Many of these features are shared with other languages that have been in the Caucasus for a long time, such as [[Ossetian language|Ossetian]] (which has ejective sounds but no ergativity). ===External relations=== Since the birth of comparative linguistics in the 19th century, the riddle of the apparently isolated Caucasian language families has attracted the attention of many scholars, who have endeavored to relate them to each other or to languages outside the Caucasus region. The most promising proposals are connections between the Northeast and Northwest Caucasian families and each other or with languages formerly spoken in [[Anatolia]] and northern [[Mesopotamia]]. ====North Caucasian languages==== {{main|North Caucasian languages}} Linguists such as [[Sergei Starostin]] see the Northeast (Nakh-Dagestanian) and Northwest (AbkhazâAdyghe) families as related and propose uniting them in a single '''North Caucasian''' family, sometimes called '''Caucasic''' or simply '''Caucasian'''. This theory excludes the South Caucasian languages, thereby proposing two indigenous language families. While these two families share many similarities, their morphological structure, with many [[morpheme]]s consisting of a single consonant, make comparison between them unusually difficult, and it has not been possible to establish a genetic relationship with any certainty. ====Ibero-Caucasian languages==== {{main|Ibero-Caucasian languages}} There are no known affinities between the South Caucasian and North Caucasian families. Nevertheless, some scholars have proposed the single name '''Ibero-Caucasian''' for all the Caucasian language families, North and South, in an attempt to unify the Caucasian languages under one family. ====Hattic==== Some linguists have claimed affinities between the Northwest Caucasian (Circassian) family and the extinct [[Hattic language]] of central Anatolia. See the article on [[Northwest Caucasian languages]] for details. ====Alarodian==== {{Main|Alarodian languages}} Alarodian is a proposed connection between Northeast Caucasian and the extinct [[Hurro-Urartian languages]] of [[Anatolia]]. ====DenÃ©âCaucasian macrofamily==== {{Main|DenÃ©âCaucasian languages}} Linguists such as [[Sergei Starostin]] have proposed a [[DenÃ©âCaucasian languages|DenÃ©âCaucasian]] [[macrofamily]], which includes the North Caucasian languages together with [[Basque language|Basque]], [[Burushaski language|Burushaski]], [[Na-DenÃ© languages|Na-DenÃ©]], [[Sino-Tibetan languages|Sino-Tibetan]], and [[Yeniseian languages|Yeniseian]]. This proposal is rejected by most linguists. ==Families with wider distribution== Other languages historically and currently spoken in the Caucasus area can be placed into families with a much wider geographical distribution. ===Indo-European=== The predominant [[Indo-European languages|Indo-European]] language in the Caucasus is [[Armenian language|Armenian]], spoken by the [[Armenians]] (circa 11 million speakers). The Ossetians, speaking the [[Ossetian language]], form another group of around 700,000 speakers. Other Indo-European languages spoken in the Caucasus include [[Greek language|Greek]] ([[Pontic Greek]]), [[Persian language|Persian]] (including [[Tat language (Caucasus)|Tat Persian]]), [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]], [[Talysh language|Talysh]], [[Judeo-Tat language|Judeo-Tat]], and the [[Slavic languages]], such as [[Russian language|Russian]] and [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]], whose speakers number over a third of the total population of the Caucasus. ===Semitic (Afro-Asiatic)=== Two dialects of [[Neo-Aramaic languages|Neo-Aramaic]] are spoken in the Caucasus: [[Assyrian Neo-Aramaic]], with around 30,000 speakers, and [[Bohtan Neo-Aramaic]], with around 1,000 speakers. Both of these were brought to the Caucasus by ethnic [[Assyrian people|Assyrians]] fleeing [[Assyrian Genocide]] during [[World War One]]. A dialect of [[Arabic language|Arabic]] known as [[Shirvani Arabic]] was spoken natively in parts of [[Azerbaijan]] and [[Dagestan]] throughout medieval times until the early 20th century.{{cite book|last=Owens|first=Jonathan|title=Arabic As a Minority Language|year=2000|publisher=[[Walter de Gruyter]]|isbn=9783110165784|pages=89â101}}{{cite book|last=Zelkina|first=Anna|title=In Quest for God and Freedom: The Sufi Response to the Russian Advance in the North Caucasus|year=2000|publisher=[[C. Hurst & Co.]]|isbn=9781850653844|page=31}} In the nineteenth century, it was considered that the best [[Modern Standard Arabic|literary Arabic]] was spoken in the mountains of [[Dagestan]].{{cite book|last=Bryan|first=Fanny. E.B.|editor-last=Bennigsen-Broxup|editor-first=Marie|editor-link=Marie Bennigsen-Broxup|title=The North Caucasus Barrier: The Russian Advance Towards the Muslim World|year=1992|publisher=[[C. Hurst & Co.]]|isbn=9781850653059|page=210}} ===Turkic=== Several [[Turkic languages]] are spoken in the Caucasus. Of these, [[Azerbaijani language|Azerbaijani]] is predominant, with around 9 million speakers in Azerbaijan and more than 10 million in North Western Iran. Other Turkic languages spoken include [[Karachay-Balkar language|Karachay-Balkar]], [[Kumyk language|Kumyk]], [[Nogai language|Nogai]], [[Turkish language|Turkish]], and [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]]. ===Mongolic=== The [[Kalmyk language]], spoken by descendants of [[Oirat language|Oirat]]-speakers from East Asia, is a [[Mongolic languages|Mongolic]] language. ==See also== *[[Caucasus]] *[[Peoples of the Caucasus]] *[[Regions of Europe]] *[[Transcaucasia]] {{portal|Language|Europe}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{colbegin}} *[http://midoil.co.uk/mailman/listinfo/cauclang_midoil.co.uk Caucasian Languages (North and South) Academic Mailing List], run by the Ravenscraig Press *[http://www.hunmagyar.org/turan/caucasus/index.html Map of the Languages of the Caucasus] *TITUS: Caucasian languages [http://titus.uni-frankfurt.de/didact/karten/kauk/kaukasm.htm map by Jost Gippert]& projects [http://armazi.uni-frankfurt.de/ Armazi]& [http://titus.fkidg1.uni-frankfurt.de/ecling/ecling.htm Ecling] *[http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/commonwealth/ethnocaucasus.jpg CIA ethnolinguistic map] *[http://linguistics.buffalo.edu/people/faculty/dryer/dryer/map.caucasus.GIF language-family map by Matthew Dryer] *[http://www.eki.ee/books/redbook/languages.html Caucausian section of the Red Book of the Peoples of the Russian Empire] *[http://www.ling.lu.se/persons/Arthur/caucprojreport.pdf The Iberian-Caucasian Connection in a Typological Perspective] â An in-depth linguistic study of Basque, Georgian, and other ergative languages, concluding that the similarities are not strong enough to prove a genetic link. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070917141516/http://linguarium.iling-ran.ru/publications/caucas/alw_cau_content.shtml Atlas of the Caucasian Languages with very detailed Language Guide (by Yuri B. Koryakov)] *[http://www.humnet.ucla.edu/pies/pdfs/IESV/1/VVI_Horse.pdf Comparative Notes on Hurro-Urartian, Northern Caucasian and Indo-European] by [[Vyacheslav Ivanov (philologist)|V. V. Ivanov]] {{colend}} {{Languages of the Caucasus}} {{navboxes| |list1 = {{Languages of Russia}} {{Caucasian (areal) languages}} {{Northeast Caucasian languages}} {{Northwest Caucasian languages}} {{Kartvelian languages}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Caucasus, Languages}} [[Category:Agglutinative languages]] [[Category:Languages of the Caucasus| ]]

This article is an outline of the '''grammar of [[Lingua Franca Nova]]''' (a.k.a. LFN, Elefen), a proposed international auxiliary language originally created by C. George Boeree and elaborated by the members of the LFN community. LFN has an analytic grammar and resembles the grammars of languages such as the [[Haitian Creole]], [[Papiamento]], and [[Afrikaans]]. On the other hand, it uses a vocabulary drawn from several modern romance languages â [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Catalan language|Catalan]], [[French language|French]], and [[Italian language|Italian]].Harrison, Richard H. (2008) ''Lingua Franca Nova.'' '''Invented Languages, 1,''' pp. 30 â33.Fisahn, Stefan (2005) ''Plansprache: Lingua Franca Nova.'' '''Contraste''', '''244''', p. 12. Complete grammars are available in English, French, Esperanto, and LFN.[http://ccgi.esperanto.plus.com/lfn/grammar.pdf LFN Grammar] ==Word order== LFN has a strict [[word order]]. The general word order is: :''subject noun phrase'' â ''verb phrase'' (â ''object noun phrase'') ::''Joan core'' â "John runs" ::''Maria oia Joan'' â "Maria hears John" A [[noun phrase]] has this order: : (''determiners'' â) (''quantifiers'' â) ''noun'' (â ''adjectives'') ::''La tre omes grande...'' â "The three large men..." ::''La multe femes peti...'' â "The many small women..." A [[verb phrase]] has this order: : (''tense/mood'' â) (''leading verb'' â) ''verb'' (â ''adverb'') ::''...ia nesesa come rapida'' â "...needed to eat quickly..." ::''...va debe come lente'' â "...will have to eat slowly..." A [[Adpositional phrase|prepositional phrase]] generally follows what it modifies, and has this order: : ''preposition'' â ''noun phrase'' ::''...en la cosina'' â "...in the kitchen" ::''...pos medianote'' â "...after midnight" ==Nouns== The roles of [[nouns]] in a sentence are indicated through prepositions and word order. There are no [[Grammatical case|cases]]. Nouns are commonly preceded by [[determiner]]s. [[Plural]] nouns are formed by appending '''''-s''''' to nouns ending in vowels or '''''-es''''' to nouns ending in consonants. This does not alter the stress: *''casa > casa'''s''''' â house > houses *''fem > fem'''es''''' â woman > women [[Mass noun]]s include liquids, powders, and substances, such as ''acua'' (water), ''arena'' (sand), and ''lenio'' (wood). They do not normally require determiners or the plural. However, one may add these to indicate specific examples or different types: *''la acua'' â the water (e.g. in the cup) *''lenios'' â woods (e.g. various kinds) [[Grammatical gender|Gender]] is typically not indicated. If necessary, nouns may be followed by '''''mas''''' (male) or '''''fema''''' (female): *''un cavalo '''mas''''' / ''un cavalo '''fema''''' â a stallion / a mare A few terms for family members and traditional roles do show distinctions of gender. For example: *''madre / padre'' â mother / father *''fi'''o''' / fi'''a''''' â son / daughter *''prinse / prins'''esa''''' â prince / princess [[Apposition]] â the use of one noun to modify another â is mostly limited to names and titles: *''san Josef'' â Saint Joseph *''mea sore Maria'' â my sister Mary == Determiners == [[Determiner (linguistics)|Determiners]] in LFN precede the noun they modify. There are two [[Article (grammar)|articles]]: '''''la''''' (the) and '''''un''''' (a), used as in English: * '''''la''' om, '''un''' fem, e enfantes'' â the man, a woman, and children Other words function similarly: :{| style="width: 90%" |- | style="width: 45%" | '''''tota''''' â all
'''''esta''''' â this, these
'''''acel''''' â that, those
'''''cada''''' â every, each
'''''cualce''''' â whatever, whichever
'''''alga''''' â some, several, a few
'''''no''''' â no, zero || '''''multe''''' â many, much
'''''poca''''' â few, little
'''''plu''''' â more
'''''min''''' â less, fewer
'''''otra''''' â other
'''''mesma''''' â same
'''''tal''''' â such |} In addition, numbers and possessive determiners (see below) are also used. ==Pronouns== Personal [[pronoun]]s are invariant: :{| style="width: 90%" |- | style="width: 45%" | '''''me''''' â I, me
'''''tu''''' â you (singular)
'''''el''''' â she, her, he, him
'''''lo''''' â it || '''''nos''''' â we, us
'''''vos''''' â you (plural)
'''''los''''' â they, them
'''''on''''' â one |} '''''El''''' is used for people and higher animals. Its use can be extended metaphorically to lower animals, robots, the moon, hurricanes, etc. '''''Lo''''' is used for things, simple animals, plants, ideas, etc. The exact dividing line is left to the speaker. There is an indefinite pronoun '''''on''''', which is used like German "man" or French "on": * '''''On''' debe segue la regulas'' â "One must follow the rules." There are no [[grammatical gender|gender]] distinctions between "he" and "she". If gender is significant, one can use words like '''''la fem, la om, la fia, la fio, la fema, la mas''''' (the woman, the man, the daughter, the son, the female, the male), etc, or gender-irrelevant terms such as '''''la plu grande''''', '''''la carnor''''', or '''''la otra''''' (the bigger one, the butcher, the other one). Unlike in the Romance languages, there is no polite/impolite contrast for the second person: '''''tu''''' is always used for the singular, '''''vos''''' always for the plural. The reflexive pronouns are also '''''me, nos, tu,''''' and '''''vos'''''. For the third person, singular and plural, lfn uses '''''se''''': * ''Me ia lava '''me''''' â "I washed myself." * ''El ama '''se''''' â "He loves himself," "She loves herself." The [[possessive]] determiners are '''''mea, nosa, tua,''''' and '''''vosa'''''. '''''Sua''''' is used for all third persons: * '''''Tua''' gato es ala'' â "Your cat is over there." *''Tu es sempre en '''mea''' mente'' â "You are always in my mind." For the possessive pronouns, LFN uses the possessive determiners, preceded by '''''la''''': * '''''La mea''' es plu grande ca '''la tua''''' â "Mine is bigger than yours." Other pronouns include the following: :{| style="width: 90%" |- | style="width: 45%" | '''''cadun''''' â everyone, everybody
'''''algun''''' â someone, somebody
'''''cualcun''''' â anyone, anybody
'''''nun''''' â no one, nobody
'''''esta''''' â this, these
'''''multe''''' â much | '''''cada cosa''''' â everything
'''''alga cosa''''' â something
'''''cualce cosa''''' â whatever, anything
'''''no cosa''''' â nothing
'''''acel''''' â that
'''''poca''''' â little |} ==Verbs== There are no [[grammatical conjugation|conjugations]] of [[verb]]s in LFN. The basic form remains the same regardless of person, number, or tense. The [[present tense]] is represented by the basic verb: *''La om '''come''''' â "The man eats", "The man is eating." The present tense is also used to indicate habitual actions and states, facts of nature, and as a "historical" tense, such as when relating a story that has been clearly established as occurring in the past: *''La sol '''leva''' en la este'' â "The sun rises in the east." *''Me '''labora''' a la universia'' â "I work at the university." The [[past tense]] is indicated by the particle '''''ia''''': *''Maria '''ia''' come'' â "Maria ate." The [[future tense]] is indicated by the particle '''''va''''': *''Joan '''va''' come pronto'' â "John will eat soon." The particle '''''ta''''' indicates the [[irrealis mood]] and can be used where other languages might use a [[Conditional mood|conditional]] or [[subjunctive]] mood. Its use is optional: *''Me ia duta ce el '''ta''' vade'' â "I doubted he would go." *''Me '''ta''' es felis si la sol '''ta''' brilia'' â "I would be happy if the sun were shining." One combination â '''''ia ta''''' â is used to express "would have": *''Me '''ia ta''' es un bon re'' â "I would have been a good king." Certain [[adverbs]] and verbal constructions add precision to the tenses: * ''Me come '''aora''''' â "I am eating now." *''Me ia come '''ja''''' â "I ate already", "I have eaten", "I had eaten." * ''Me va come '''a pos''''' â "I will eat afterwards." * ''Me ia '''fini''' leje la libro'' â "I (have) finished reading the book." * '''''Doman''', me va '''comensa''' leje un otra'' â "Tomorrow, I will begin to read another." [[Negation (linguistics)|Negation]] is indicated by putting '''''no''''' before the tense particle or (in the present tense) the verb. Double negatives should be avoided: *''El '''no''' ia pensa ce algun ia es asi'' â "He didn't think anyone was here." [[Imperative mood|Commands]] are indicated by dropping the subject pronoun. [[Hortative]] sentences include the subject, but are preceded by '''''ta ce''''': * ''Boli la acua!'' â "Boil the water!" * '''''Ta ce''' nos dansa!'' â "Let's dance!" "Shall we dance?" '''''Lo''''' and '''''on''''' are used as [[dummy pronoun]]s before verbs that refer to weather or other general situations: * ''Lo va pluve'' â "It's going to rain." * ''Lo es tro calda en esta sala'' â "It is too hot in this room." (Or ''Esta sala es tro calda'') * ''Lo pare ce tu es coreta'' â "It seems that you are correct." * ''On no ave pexes en esta lago'' â "There aren't fish in this lake." (Or ''No pexes es en esta lago'') A verb that is fundamentally [[intransitive verb|intransitive]] may be used as a transitive [[Causative|causal verb]] by moving the original subject to the object position, and adding a new subject: * ''La acua ia boli'' â "The water boiled" > ''Me ia boli la acua'' - "I boiled the water." * ''La porte ia abri'' â "The door opened" > ''Me ia abri la porte'' â "I opened the door." Verbs can be made into adjectives: The [[participle|active participle]] is formed by adding '''''-nte''''' to the verb. For example, ''come'' becomes ''come'''nte''''', meaning "eating". This should never be used as a gerund, as it often is in English (e.g. "I love eating"). One can emphasize the idea that the subject is in the midst of an activity or process ([[Continuous and progressive aspects|the progressive aspect]]) using the active participle. Or one can use expressions such as ''en la media de'': *''Nos ia '''es comente''' cuando la tempesta ia comensa'' â "We were eating when the storm began." *''Nos ia es '''en la media de come''' cuando la tempesta ia comensa'' â "We were in the middle of eating when the storm began." The [[participle|passive participle]] is formed by adding '''''-da''''' to the verb. For example, ''come'' becomes ''come'''da''''', meaning "eaten". This should not be confused with the past tense. The passive participle can be used to express the [[grammatical voice|passive voice]]. Or one can usa a generic subject pronoun instead: *''Si tu no asconde la torta, '''lo va es comeda''''' â "If you don't hide the cake, it will be eaten." *''Si tu no asconde la torta, '''algun va come lo''''' â "If you don't hide the cake, someone will eat it." Verbs can be used as nouns without change by adding '''''la''''' or other determiner. Without a determiner, the word serves as an [[infinitive]] or [[gerund]]: *''La samba es '''un''' dansa.'' â "The samba is a dance." *''Do es '''la''' dansa?'' â "Where is the dance?" *''Los gusta dansa.'' â "They like to dance," "They like dancing." In LFN, verbs often come in pairs. Some "leading" verbs are like [[modal verbs]] in English. However, the idea of leading verbs goes beyond modals to include "attitudinal" verbs such as '''''finje''''' (pretend) and '''''pare''''' (seem). There is no equivalent to the word "to," and the "following" verb is left in its simplest form: *''Me va '''atenta vola''' doman.'' â "I will try to fly tomorrow." *''On '''debe brosi''' la dentes a cada dia.'' â "One should brush one's teeth every day." [[Predicative expression|Subject complements]] are introduced by '''''es''''' and words such as '''''pare''''' (seem) and '''''deveni''''' (become): *''la fem ia '''es bela'''''. â "The woman was beautiful." *''Me va '''deveni un psicolojiste''''' â "I will become a psychologist." [[Predicative expression|Object complements]] are introduced by the preposition '''''a''''': *''Me ia pinta la casa '''a roja'''''. â "I painted the house red." * ''Los ia eleje el '''a presidente'''''. â "They elected him president." ==Adjectives== [[Adjective]]s follow the noun they modify, with two exceptions: '''''Bon''''' (good) and '''''mal''''' (bad) may come before the noun, due to their frequent use. Unlike the natural Romance languages, adjectives in LFN do not have gender or plural forms, i.e. they don't "agree" with the nouns they describe. The [[comparative]] is made with '''''plu''''' (more) or '''''min''''' (less). "The most" is '''''la plu''''' and "the least" is '''''la min:''''' *''Jan es '''plu''' bon '''ca''' Jo, ma Jil es '''la plu''' bon.'' â "Jan is better than Jo, but Jill is the best." Equivalence is indicated with '''''tan... como''''': *''Marco es '''tan''' grande '''como''' Mona.'' â "Mark is as big as Mona." Like verbs, adjectives can be used as nouns. For example, ''bela'' means "beautiful", but ''un bela'' means "a beautiful one" or "a beauty." This works with participles, too: ''la studiante'' and ''la studiada'' mean "the student" and "the studied," respectively, from the verb ''studia,'' "study." An adjective can be made into an [[abstract noun]] by adding '''''-ia''''' (-ity, -ness, -ship, -hood). In this way ''bela'' becomes ''bel'''ia''','' meaning beauty. This can also be used with nouns: ''madre'' (mother) becomes ''madr'''ia''''' (motherhood). ==Adverbs== LFN doesn't have an explicit way of marking [[adverb]]s. Instead, any adjective can be used as an adverb by placing it after a verb or at the very beginning of the sentence. ''Un om felis'' for example means "a happy man", whereas ''el dansa felis'' means "he/she dances happily". Adverbs used to modify adjectives ''precede'' the adjective. Dedicated adverbs, such as ''aora'' and ''oji'' can fall anywhere, as long as they don't cause confusion. Examples of common adverbs include the following: :{| style="width: 90%" |- | style="width: 45%" | '''''aora''''' â now
'''''alora''''' â then
'''''ancora''''' â still, yet
'''''ja''''' â already
'''''sempre''''' â always
'''''nunca''''' â never
'''''cuasi''''' â almost
'''''an''''' â even || '''''ier''''' â yesterday
'''''oji''''' â today
'''''doman''''' â tomorrow
'''''asi''''' â here
'''''ala''''' â there
'''''tro''''' â too
'''''apena''''' â barely, scarcely
'''''cisa''''' â maybe |} ==Prepositions== [[Preposition]]s are placed before the noun or noun phrase, and the [[Adpositional phrase|prepositional phrase]] is placed after the noun being modified, or, if used adverbially, at the beginning of the sentence or after the verb. There are 22 basic prepositions in LFN: :{| style="width: 90%" |- | style="width: 45%" | '''''a''''' â at, to
'''''ante''''' â before, in front of
'''''asta''''' â until
'''''ca''''' â than
'''''como''''' â like
'''''con''''' â with
'''''contra''''' â against
'''''de''''' â of, from, since
'''''en''''' â in, into, during
'''''entre''''' â between, among
'''''estra''''' â out of, except || '''''longo''''' â along
'''''par''''' â by
'''''per''''' â for, in order to
'''''pos''''' â after, behind, according to
'''''sin''''' â without
'''''sirca''''' â around, approximately
'''''su''''' â below, under, beneath
'''''supra''''' â above, over
'''''sur''''' â on, about, concerning
'''''tra''''' â through
'''''ultra''''' â beyond, past, across |} Some prepositions can be used as adverbs by placing '''''a''''' or '''''de''''' before them. *'''''a su''''' â down, below, downstairs *'''''a pos''''' â after, afterwards, behind, out back *'''''de supra''''' â from above ==Coordinating conjunctions== There are three [[Grammatical conjunction|coordinating conjunctions]] in LFN and three correlative conjunctions: :{| style="width: 90%" |- | style="width: 45%" | '''''e''''' â and
'''''o''''' â or
'''''ma''''' â but, yet || '''''e ... e ...''''' â both ... and ...
'''''o ... o ...''''' â either ... or ...
'''''no ... (e) no ...''''' â neither ... nor ... | |} ==Questions== There are a number of [[interrogative word]]s that are used to introduce [[question]]s:Christo Moskovsky & Alan Libert (2006) Questions in Natural and Artificial Languages. '''Journal of Universal Language 7''', pp 65-120 http://www.unish.org/upload/word/7-2-03-QuestionsInNat%26ALs2.pdf :{| style="width: 90%" |- | style="width: 45%" |'''''cual''''' â what, which
'''''ci''''' â who, whom
'''''de ci''''' â whose, of whom
'''''cuando''''' â when || '''''do''''' â where
'''''como''''' â how
'''''cuanto''''' â how much, how many
'''''perce''''' â why |} (Most of these are also used to introduce [[subordinate clause]]s, discussed below.) For example: * '''''Cuanto''' on paia per lete asi?'' â "How much does one pay for milk here?" * '''''Cual''' auto tu gusta la plu?'' â "Which car do you like the best?" * '''''Perce''' tu no gusta esta?'' â "Why don't you like this one?" * '''''Cuando''' tu espeta ce el ariva?'' â "When do you expect him to arrive?" Questions may include one of these words or may be indicated by rising intonation alone. One may also express questions by beginning the sentence with the interrogative particle '''''esce''''' ("is it that... ?") or by adding '''''no''''' (no) or '''''si''''' (yes) to the end of the sentence. In writing, questions always end with a question mark (?): * '''''Como''' on construi un casa per avias?'' â "How do you make a bird house?" * ''Tu vole dansa?'' â "Do you want to dance?" * '''''Esce''' tu parla Deutx?'' â "Do you speak German?" * ''Tu parla Italian, '''no'''?'' â "You speak Italian, don't you?" ==Clauses== [[Relative clauses]] (or adjective clauses) function like adjectives. There are two [[relative pronouns]] which typically introduce relative clauses: : '''''cual''''' â which, that : '''''ci''''' â who, whom Relative clauses follow the noun or noun phrase that they modify: * ''La fem '''ci''' me ama veni de Frans.'' â "The woman (whom) I love comes from France." * ''La robot '''cual''' me ia construi no opera.'' â "The robot (that) I built doesn't work." * ''Me no comprende lo '''cual''' tu intende.'' â "I don't understand what you mean." Relative pronouns may be preceded by prepositions: * ''La cosa '''per cual''' me espera la plu es un bisicle nova.'' â "The thing I wish for the most is a new bicycle." * ''La fem '''de ci''' nos parla labora a la me ofisia.'' â "The woman of whom we speak works at my office." '''''Cuando''''' and '''''do''''' can also be used to introduce relative clauses: * ''Esta es la site '''do''' me vole abita.'' â "This is the city where I want to live." * ''Me ia vade ala en la anio '''cuando''' me ia fini mea studias.'' â "I went there in the year when I finished my studies." [[Dependent clause#Noun_clause|Noun clauses]] function the same way that nouns and noun phrases do in a sentence. Two [[subordinating conjunctions]] commonly introduce noun clauses: : '''''ce''''' â that : '''''esce''''' â whether For example: * ''Me pensa '''ce''' el es bela.'' â "I think that she is beautiful." * ''La gato entra la sala '''sin ce''' algun vide el.'' â "The cat entered the room without anyone seeing it." * ''Me demanda a me '''esce''' el ama me.'' â "I wonder whether she loves me." Relative pronouns and interrogative words can also introduce noun clauses: * ''Me no pote recorda '''ci''' me es.'' â "I can't remember who I am." * ''Me gusta '''como''' el parla.'' â "I like how he talks." * ''Me no sabe '''cuando''' me va parti.'' â I don't know when I will leave." *''Me sabe '''cual''' tu desira per natal'' â "I know what you want for Christmas." [[Dependent clause#Adverbial_clause|Adverbial clauses]] function like adverbs, modifying the verb or the sentence as a whole. Some are introduced by these subordinating conjunctions: : '''''si''''' â if : '''''afin''''' â so that, in order that : '''''car''''' â because Adverbial clauses usually follow the main clause: * ''Me ta pote vade '''si''' me ta ave un auto.'' â "I would be able to go if I had a car." * ''Me no teme la can '''car''' el es multe peti.'' â "I am not afraid of the dog because it is very small." * ''Me core '''afin''' la rinoseros no catura me.'' â "I'm running so that the rhinos don't catch me." Some of the interrogative words can also be used to introduce adverbial clauses: * ''La lupos cria '''cuando''' los vide la luna'' â "The wolves howl when they see the moon." * ''Me vole abita '''do''' la clima es bon'' â "I want to live where the weather is good." * ''Me vive '''como''' me vole vive.'' â "I live as I want to live." '''''Do''''' and '''''cuando''''' are often preceded by prepositions: :{| style="width: 90%" |- | style="width: 45%" | '''''a do''''' â to where, whither
'''''de do''''' â from where, whence
'''''de cuando''''' â since
|| '''''pos cuando''''' â after
'''''en cuando''''' â while
'''''asta cuando''''' â until |} For example: * ''El ia pote sci '''ante cuando''' el ia pote pasea.'' â "He could ski before he could walk." * ''Me gusta escuta a la radio '''en cuando''' me labora.'' â "I like to listen to the radio while I work." ==Numbers== Numbers in LFN are as follows: :{| style="width: 90%" |- | style="width: 45%" | 0 â '''''zero'''''
1 â '''''un'''''
2 â '''''du'''''
3 â '''''tre'''''
4 â '''''cuatro'''''
5 â '''''sinco''''' || 6 â '''''ses'''''
7 â '''''sete'''''
8 â '''''oto'''''
9 â '''''nove'''''
10 â '''''des''''' |} Higher numbers are constructed as follows: :{| style="width: 90%" |- | style="width: 45%" | 11 â '''''des-un'''''
20 â '''''dudes'''''
100 â '''''sento'''''
321 â '''''tresento-dudes-un'''''|| 1000 â '''''mil'''''
45 678 â '''''cuatrodes-sinco mil sessento-setedes-oto'''''
1 000 000 â '''''milion'''''
1 000 000 000 â '''''mil milion''''' |} Numbers that express quantity precede the noun; numbers that express order follow the noun: *''la '''tre''' omes,'' "the three men" *''la om '''tre''','' "the third man" Fractions are constructed with '''''-i,''''' e.g. '''''dui, tri, cuatri,... desi, senti, mili,''''' etc. These are also used as verbs meaning "to halve", "to divide into three parts", etc. Multiples and groups can be referred to with '''''-uple,''''' as in '''''duple''''' â "double, duo, couple, pair". Add '''''-i''''' to make a verb, such as '''''dupli''''' - "to double". ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Constructed languages}} [[Category:International auxiliary languages]] [[Category:Grammars of specific languages]] [[Category:Grammars of constructed languages]]

{{Dutch dialects}}
'''Low Dietsch''' ({{lang-nl|Platdiets}}, {{lang-li|Platduutsj}}, {{lang-fr|francique rhÃ©no-mosan}} or {{lang|fr|platdutch}}) refers to a handful of transitional [[Limburgish]]â[[Ripuarian language|Ripuarian]] dialects spoken in a number of towns and villages (e.g., Gemmenich, [[Hombourg, Belgium|Hombourg]], Montzen, [[Welkenraedt]]). {|style="border:1px solid lightblue;" |style="background-color:steelblue; color:white; text-align:center;" | Language situation in the northeast of the Belgian province of LiÃ¨ge |- |[[Image:Platdietsestreek.png|400px|center]] |- | align="left" | Schematic map of the Low Dietsch language area (''Platdietse streek'') in Belgium. {{legend|#99002F|[[Flemish Community|Dutch and Limburgish]] ([[Limburg (Belgium)|Belgian Limburg]])}} {{legend|#009400|[[French Community of Belgium|French and Walloon]] ([[LiÃ¨ge (province)|Province of LiÃ¨ge]])}} {{legend|#FF7E00|Low Dietsch}} {{legend|#2E3699|[[German-speaking Community of Belgium|Middle Franconian]] (cantons of [[Eupen]] and [[Saint Vith]])}} {{legend|white|outline=white|text=■|[[Municipalities with language facilities]]}} |} This area, located in the Belgian ([[Wallonia|Walloon]]) "tri-state area" from [[Voeren]] (Fourons), to [[PlombiÃ¨res]] ([[Bleiberg]]), to [[Eupen]], is called the Low Dietsch zone ({{lang-nl|Platdietse streek}}). Classified by German dialectologists as [[Ripuarian language|Ripuarian Franconian]] and by Dutch-language dialectologists as [[Southeast Limburgish]], Low Dietsch is more precisely a transitional dialect between both. Low Dietsch is one of several [[Meuse-Rhenish]] varieties that make the north-western part of the [[dialect continuum]] known as the [[Rhenish fan]]. As the southernmost dialect of Limburgish, the Low-Dietsch speech area corresponds to the core of the old [[Duchy of Limburg]].
==French usage==
In French, the term {{lang|fr|francique carolingien}} ("Carolingian Franconian") is also used,<ref name="Le Soir">[http://www.lesoir.be/regions/liege/culture-pour-sauver-la-langue-2007-08-07-543405.shtml Obelit au secours du patois], ''[[Le Soir]]''</ref> because it is thought to be the language of the [[Carolingian]] dynasty and court, although that would be an [[anachronism]]. Low Dietsch is thought to have been spoken from [[Tongeren]] to [[Cologne]], which would presumably make it the likeliest candidate for [[Charlemagne]]'s native language.<ref name="Le Soir"/> However, this expression is controversial since there is no way to prove that hypothesis. Nor is it possible that the current dialectal map was the same 1,500 years ago. Of those early documents that have survived, one, the [[Oaths of Strasbourg|Strasbourg Oaths]] (AD 842), is in [[Rhine Franconian]], and the other, the ''Wachtendonck Psalms'' (10th century), is in a form of southern Limburgish (with a few [[Ripuarian language|Ripuarian Franconian]] traits).
In 1963 the Low Dietsch zone was incorporated to [[Wallonia]], and since 1992 the dialect has been recognized as a "regional language" by the Walloon authority, affording it certain rights and protections. It is not, however, related to Walloon, but French is the language of officialdom in the area. It forms the northwestern border of [[Ripuarian language|Ripuarian Franconian]] and the southeastern portion of the [[Meuse-Rhenish]] area. {|style="border:1px solid lightblue;" |style="background-color:steelblue; color:white; text-align:center;" | Language situation in Belgium |- |[[File:Languages in Belgium.jpg|400px|center]] |- |Language situation in Belgium. The Low Dietsch area is marked as ''Dutch, French & German'' |}
==Southeast Limburgish== '''[[Southeast Limburgish]]''' ({{lang-nl|Zuidoost-Limburgs}}), as spoken around [[Kerkrade]], [[Bocholtz]] and [[Vaals]] in the Netherlands, [[Aachen]] in Germany and [[Raeren]] and [[Eynatten]] in Belgium, also shows the gradual transition from Limburgish towards Ripuarian. It is adjacent to the southeastern border of the Meuse-Rhenish language area, and is related to [[Southern Meuse-Rhenish]]. Limburgish straddles the borderline between Low Franconian and West Central German varieties. They are more-or-less mutually intelligible with the Ripuarian dialects, but show fewer [[High German consonant shift|'High German shifts']] (R. Hahn 2001).
Dialects belonging to the Ripuarian group almost always call themselves ''Platt'' like ''Ãcher Platt'' (of Aachen) or ''Eischwiele Platt'' (of Eschweiler). The reason behind this is, that most of the far more than hundred Ripuarian dialects are bound to a village or municipality. Usually there are small distinctive differences between neighboring dialects, and increasingly bigger ones between the more distant ones. These are described by a set of [[isogloss]]es called the 'Rhenish fan' (''Rheinischer FÃ¤cher'' in linguistics). The way someone talks, even if he is not using Ripuarian, quite often makes it possible to trace him precisely to the village or city quarter where he learned to speak.
Currently, all varieties within a half circle some 15â20 km around Aachen, including two-thirds of Dutch South Limburg and also the Low Dietsch area between [[Voeren]] and [[Eupen]] in Belgium, can be considered a group of its own, which recently has been named '''Limburgish of the Three Countries''' ({{lang-nl|Drielandenlimburgs}}, {{lang-de|DreilÃ¤nderplatt}}), referring to the place where the Netherlands, Belgium, and Germany meet (Frins 2005).{{fix|text=full citation needed|date=September 2017}} This variety still possesses interesting syntactic idiosyncrasies, probably dating from the period when the old Duchy of Limburg existed.
==Classification== * [[Indo-European languages|Indo-European]] ** [[Germanic languages|Germanic]] *** [[West Germanic languages|West Germanic]] **** [[East Low Franconian]] / [[West Central German|Middle Franconian]] ***** [[Limburgish language|Limburgish]]â[[Ripuarian language|Ripuarian]] / Low Dietsch
==See also== * [[Southern Meuse-Rhenish]] * [[Ripuarian language]] * ''[[:fr:Thiois|Thiois]]'' in the [[French Wikipedia]] {{fr icon}} * ''[[:nl:Zuidoost-Limburgs|Zuidoost-Limburgs]]'' in the [[Dutch Wikipedia]] {{nl icon}} * [[Eupen-Malmedy]]
== References == {{refbegin}} * Ad Welschen, 2000-2005: Course ''Dutch Society and Culture'', International School for Humanities and Social Studies ISHSS, Universiteit van Amsterdam. {{refend}} {{reflist}}
==External links== * Belgian Tri-state Area: [http://www.trois-frontieres.be/F/sit_geo.php Trois frontiÃ¨res]. * [http://projetbabel.org/forum/viewtopic.php?t=9969 Projet babel] * [http://www.remersdael.be/Histoire/patois.html Notre patois, notre "Platdutch"] * [http://users.telenet.be/sf15116/Platt/ Dictionnaire du patois de Gemmenich]
